title: Cyclists clear snow from Comm. Ave. bike lanes after storm, call on city for accountability
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Volunteers from Boston Cyclists Union and BU's Urbanism Club cleared snow from bike lanes on Commonwealth Avenue.
Advocates filed 311 reports and contacted officials, citing snow-covered bike lanes as a safety and equity issue.
City removed 92,000 cubic yards of snow, but communication with cycling advocates remains poor, say activists.

title: 7 things to do this Valentine’s Day weekend
author: Kelly Chan
bullets: Boston Frostival at Copley Square features pizza-making, live jazz, arts and crafts, and a silent headphone movie experience.
Novo Lantern, Boxfish, and K-Bok offer diverse Asian cuisines, coinciding with Boston's Lunar New Year Festival Gala on Feb. 15.
Free community ice skating events are available at Canal District Kendall and the Boston Common Frog Pond on Feb. 14 and Feb. 15.

title: City’s police oversight agency is finally starting to subpoena Boston cops
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: Boston's Office of Police Accountability and Transparency (OPAT) has subpoenaed nine police officers for a meeting on February 12.
The decision follows complaints of a "widespread refusal" by Boston Police Department personnel to cooperate with OPAT investigations.
Subpoenaed officers' testimonies will occur in a closed-session, with potential court action if they fail to appear.

title: Third wheels are the best wheels
author: Meredith Goldstein
bullets: Meredith Goldstein discusses the concept of third wheeling in relationships, highlighting its often underestimated benefits.
Elaine Hoan, a researcher at the University of Toronto, notes couples may not invite singles due to a 'cocooning' effect.
Researcher Jaimie Arona Krems suggests the 'perception gap' might deter couples from inviting singles as third wheels.

title: How losing their parents led two brothers to the Boston Marathon
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Brothers Connor and Collin Nally are running the 2026 Boston Marathon for the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.
The Nally brothers aim to raise $27,000 to support cancer research, having lost both parents to cancer.
Connor and Collin run to honor family members lost to cancer, symbolizing remembrance and renewal.

title: After stage 3 blood cancer, Lynnfield woman will return for 7th Boston Marathon
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Allison Milford, 39, from Lynnfield, will run her 7th Boston Marathon in 2026 after overcoming stage 3 blood cancer.
Milford is raising funds for the Boston Athletic Association, supporting community programs for at-risk children.
She completed her first marathon in 2011 after finishing cancer treatment, marking the beginning of her marathon journey.

title: DHS criticizes city councilor after chaotic ICE arrest in Roslindale
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: DHS criticized Boston City Councilor Enrique Pepén for his comments on an ICE arrest in Roslindale on February 5.
The arrest sparked controversy after ICE agents reportedly left a vehicle in the street during the operation.
Councilor Pepén and DHS exchanged accusations, with DHS labeling the detainee a 'serial criminal illegal alien.'

title: Nice weather kicks off the holiday weekend, but will the next storm system be a hit or miss?
author: David Epstein
bullets: Pleasant weather expected Friday through Sunday with sunny skies and temperatures in the mid-30s across Southern New England.
Saturday starts cold but warms to the 20s and 30s; Sunday remains similar with increasing clouds in Southern New England.
A potential coastal storm may impact Presidents Day on Monday, but the current outlook favors minimal effects on the region.

title: What K’Lavon Chaisson and Jaylinn Hawkins said about upcoming free agency
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: K'Lavon Chaisson and Jaylinn Hawkins will enter free agency next month but express a desire to stay with the Patriots.
Chaisson, a linebacker, had a breakout season with 7.5 sacks, tied for team lead in tackles for loss.
Hawkins recorded a career-high four interceptions and emphasized his close bond with the team and coaches.

title: A Mass. middle school basketball coach collapsed during a game. The opposing coach sprang into action.
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Waltham coach Ronnie Poirier collapsed from a heart attack during a game at Belmont Middle School.
Belmont coach Ian Haffer, a doctor, used a defibrillator and performed CPR to save Poirier's life.
Poirier is in ICU and able to communicate while undergoing extensive testing following the incident.
